Yes, there are many famous movies that use the parallel editing technique really well. One of the most famous examples is the climax of the classic film "The Godfather" directed by Francis Ford Coppola. In this scene, parallel editing is used to cut back and forth between the baptism of Michael Corleone's nephew and the murder of rival gang members. The tense juxtaposition of a religious ceremony and brutal violence creates a powerful emotional impact.

Another example is "Rocky". In the final fight scene, parallel editing is used to alternate between shots of Rocky in the ring fighting Apollo Creed and his girlfriend Adrian watching the fight on television. The use of parallel editing adds to the suspense and tension of the fight and heightens the emotional stakes.

Finally, there's the iconic shower scene in Alfred Hitchcock's "Psycho". The use of parallel editing in this scene is used to cut back and forth between shots of Marion Crane in the shower and the shadowy figure of the killer entering the bathroom. The quick cuts and jarring close-ups create a sense of chaos and panic, making for an incredibly frightening moment in the film.

These are just a few examples of how effective parallel editing can be in creating suspense and tension in film.
